Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a medical history of asthma, COPD, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. She presented with acute on chronic dyspnea and was treated with antibiotics for pneumonia. The patient was intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure and has been in the ICU since then.

The patient's current condition is summarized as follows:

- The patient developed new-onset atrial fibrillation, which has since converted to sinus rhythm with the administration of amiodarone.
- The patient was started on heparin due to concerns of pulmonary embolism (PE), although a CT angiography (CTA) did not show any evidence of PE.
- The CTA did reveal multifocal ground glass opacities in the lungs bilaterally, with worsening consolidation in the right upper lobe posterior segment as well as bilateral lower lobes since June 18th. There are also mildly enlarged mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes that may be reactive.
- A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed normal global and regional biventricular systolic function, with no diastolic dysfunction or significant valvular disease seen. However, there is mild pulmonary hypertension.
- The patient's sputum culture grew resistant Pseudomonas, so the antibiotic regimen was broadened to include vancomycin.
- The patient's condition has been complicated by shock, which was initially suspected due to worsening leukocyt

   TTE: Normal global and regional biventricular systolic function. No
   diastolic dysfunction or significant valvular disease seen. Mild
   pulmonary hypertension.
   CTA Chest (prelim): No evidence of PE. Multifocal ground glass
   opacities in the lungs bilaterally with worsening consolidation of the
   right upper lobe posterior segment as well as bilateral lower lobes
   from [**2111-6-18**]. Mildly enlarged mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes may be
   reactive
   Assessment and Plan
   66 year-old female with PMH significant for asthma, COPD, DM,
   hypothyroidism with acute on chronic dyspnea, treated with antibiotics
   for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
   # Shock: Patient with increasing pressor requirement yesterday in the
   setting of worsened leukocytosis with new CXR infiltrates, new atrial
   Fib, and in setting of discontinued steroids. Possible etiologies
   include cardiogenic, CVL in atrium, sepsis given new pseudomonas+
   sputum cx, adrenal insufficiency, or increasing PEEP requirement. BP
   now improving s/p pharmacological conversion on amiodarone with pressor
   change, pull-back of CVL, change in abx, reinitiation of steroids, and
   decreased PEEP. No evidence of PE.
   - On vanc; zosyn changed to meropenem given pseudomonas with borderline
   sensitivities to zosyn on prelim cx
   - Switched from levophed to neosynephrine
   - Cont amiodarone, transition to po
   - Will d/c hydrocortisone and restart prednisone taper starting at 20mg
   po
   - Decrease PEEP as tolerated, follow ABGs and wean as long as Sats in
   the 90s and PaO2 in 60-70s.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially presented with H1N1 with MRSA
   superinfection and ARDS physiology; febrile yesterday to 102 with
   ?worsening RUL and bilateral lower lobe consolidations with sputum +
   for pseudomonas. Agitation and bronchospastic/cough spells have
   resolved since increasing doses of sedations.  Off lasix gtt as thought
   to be dry.
   - wean off PEEP and FiO2 as tolerated as above
   - Increase sedation (propofol, fentanyl) prn to combat coughing spells.
   - continue vanc; change meropenem for VAP as borderline sensitive to
   zosyn
   - f/u pending cx
   - f/u ID recs
   # Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile yesterday with increased leukocytosis so
   Zosyn was added and linezolid changed to vanco d/t concern for lactic
   acidosis; now has likely pseudomonas VAP. All other cx NGTD with
   exception for yeast in urine, for which foley changed.
   - Lines changed [**2111-6-20**]
   - F/u pending sputum cx, bcx, BAL cx, stool studies (CDiff neg)
   - Continue Vanco and meropenem as above, oseltamivir x 10 d (last dose
   [**6-26**])
   # Afib: [**Month (only) 11**] be [**2-16**] overdiuresis. No e/o PE. TSH pending. In sinus now
   s/p pharm conversion.
   - F/u TSH
   - Cont amio gtt and transition to po
   - Cont hep gtt for another 24 hours as stabilizing medical issues;
   reassess need to continue in AM
   # Anemia:  Unclear etiology but has been trending down since admit.
   Possibly due to phlebotomy v. vaginal bleed but no active bleed
   visualized on exam by OB/GYN. Stools guaiac negative. Fe studies
   unrevealing.
   - transfuse if < 23 or hemodynamically unstable
   #. Diabetes: Cont insulin gtt for now as critically ill and titrating
   steroids; will transition to insulin SC when more stable
   #. MS: Likely [**2-16**] meds. Head CT unhelpful for prognosis. Reassess as
   able to wean sedation.
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, DM, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with acute on chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia. She is currently intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient has shown worsening leukocytosis with new CXR infiltrates, new atrial fibrillation, and in the setting of discontinued steroids. Possible etiologies for her condition include cardiogenic shock, central venous line infection, sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, or increasing PEEP requirement. 

The patient's medical team has implemented several interventions to address these issues, including changing antibiotics, pulling back the CVL, reinitiating steroids, decreasing PEEP, and adjusting pressor support. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock: The patient's increasing pressor requirement, worsening leukocytosis, new CXR infiltrates, new atrial fibrillation, and discontinued steroids suggest the possibility of cardiogenic shock, CVL infection, sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, or increasing PEEP requirement. Immediate attention should be given to stabilize the patient's hemodynamics and address any underlying causes.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient initially presented with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, resulting in ARDS physiology. She is now febrile with worsening right upper lobe and bilateral lower lobe consolidations. Close monitoring of oxygenation and ventilation parameters

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a medical history of asthma, COPD, DM, and hypothyroidism. She presented with acute on chronic dyspnea and was treated for pneumonia. She was intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure and later diagnosed with MRSA superinfection, ARDS, and pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has also been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, metabolic alkalosis, anemia, and diabetes. She is currently on multiple medications including antibiotics for VAP, amiodarone for atrial fibrillation, steroids, and insulin for glycemic control.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock: The patient initially presented with septic shock, which improved with the change from Zosyn to meropenem, suggesting a resistant pseudomonas infection. It is important to monitor her blood pressure and ensure adequate perfusion.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for 15 days and has developed VAP. Weaning off the ventilator will be challenging, and close monitoring of oxygen saturation and PaO2 levels is necessary.
3. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient had fevers and leukocytosis, likely due to pseudomonas VAP. With the change in antibiotics to meropenem, her condition is improving.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation.

   # Shock: BPs have improved with change from zosyn to meropenem

   pharm conversion.
   - Cont amio po (currently 200mg po BID) for at least a few months
   - Cte hep gtt and hold on coumadin (CHADS2 score = 2) given need for
   trach/peg in next few days
   # Hypochloremic Metaboic Alkalosis: Unclear etiology. Acetazolamide did
   help.
   - Cte acetazolamide and monitor bicarb/volume status
   - replete with KCl to K  >4.5
   # Anemia:  Unclear etiology but has been trending down since admit.
   Possibly due to phlebotomy v. vaginal bleed but no active bleed
   visualized on exam by OB/GYN. Stools guaiac negative. Fe studies
   unrevealing.
   - transfuse if < 23 or hemodynamically unstable

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with acute on chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia. She required intubation due to hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient has multiple medical complications including shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, fevers/leukocytosis (likely pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia), atrial fibrillation, metabolic alkalosis, anemia, and diabetes.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock: The patient's blood pressure has improved with the change from Zosyn to meropenem, suggesting a possible improvement in septic shock caused by resistant pseudomonas infection.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient initially presented with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) physiology. She now has pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Tracheostomy is planned as she is unlikely to come off the ventilator soon.
3. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient's fevers and leukocytosis are likely due to pseudomonas VAP. Her condition is improving on meropenem instead of Zosyn.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient had atrial fibrillation but is now in sinus rhythm after pharmacologic conversion. Overdiuresis may have contributed to this condition.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 62-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of diabetes mellitus type I, respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, fever of unknown origin, altered mental status, impaired skin integrity, anemia secondary to blood loss, and cough. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, and CPAP/PSV mode. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 38.1°C, heart rate of 62 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 125/55 to 141/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient's ABG results indicate a pH of 7.47, PaCO2 of 46 mmHg, PaO2 of 212, and HCO3- of 29 mEq/L. The patient's laboratory results show elevated WBC count, decreased hemoglobin level, increased serum glucose level, and abnormal liver function test results. The patient's fluid balance is within normal limits, and the blood product usage has been significant.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the prolonged intubation and the presence of fever, there is a risk of developing VAP. Measures such as elevating the head of bed, performing regular mouth care, and considering appropriate antibiotic therapy should be taken

   66 year-old female with PMH significant for asthma, COPD, DM,
   hypothyroidism with acute on chronic dyspnea, treated with antibiotics
   for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
   # Shock: BPs have improved with change from zosyn to meropenem
   suggesting had resistant pseudomonas making septic shock more likely
   - Switched from levophed to neosynephrine
   - Cont amiodarone, transition to po
   - Cte prednisone taper starting at 20mg po
   - Decrease PEEP as tolerated, follow ABGs and wean as long as Sats in
   the 90s and PaO2 in 60-70s.
   - Defer diuresis as of now.
   - continue sedation at current doses for trach today.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially presented with H1N1 with MRSA
   superinfection and ARDS physiology; Now with pseudomonas VAP as well
   - Per IP, trach today as will likely not be able to come off ventilator
   soon and been on vent X 16days
   - wean off PEEP using increased sedation (try titrating fentanyl) and
   FiO2 as tolerated
   - Continue sedation (propofol, fentanyl) prn to combat coughing spells.
   - continue vanc and meropenem for VAP
   - f/u pending cx
   - f/u ID recs
   # Fevers/leukocytosis: likely [**2-16**] pseudomonas VAP. Now improving on
   meropenem instead of zosyn.
   - Lines changed [**2111-6-20**]
   - F/u pending sputum cx, bcx, BAL cx, stool studies (CDiff neg)
   - Continue Vanco and meropenem as above, oseltamivir x 10 d (last dose
   [**6-26**])
   # Afib: [**Month (only) 11**] be [**2-16**] overdiuresis. No e/o PE. TSH WNL. In sinus now s/p
   pharm conversion.
   - Cont amoi po (currently 200mg po BID x 7 days) for at least a few
   months
   - Cte hep gtt and hold on coumadin (CHADS2 score = 2) given need for
   trach/peg in next few days
   # Metaboic Alkalosis: Unclear etiology. Acetazolamide did help.
   - Cte acetazolamide and monitor bicarb
   # Anemia:  Unclear etiology but has been trending down since admit.
   Possibly due to phlebotomy v. vaginal bleed but no active bleed
   visualized on exam by OB/GYN. Stools guaiac negative. Fe studies
   unrevealing.
   - transfuse if < 23 or hemodynamically unstable
   #. Diabetes: Cont insulin gtt for now as critically ill and titrating
   steroids
   - transition to insulin SC today
   #. MS: Likely [**2-16**] meds. Head CT unhelpful for prognosis. Reassess as
   able to wean sedation.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year-old female with PMH significant for asthma, COPD, DM,
   hypothyroidism with acute on chronic dyspnea, treated with antibiotics
   for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially presented with H1N1 with MRSA
   superinfection and ARDS physiology; Now with pseudomonas VAP as well.
   [**Month (only) 11**] have mild component of fluid overload as 15L net positive over LOS
   (not accounting for insensible losses).
   - Plan for trach placement today as at PEEP goal of 10 and FiO2 goal of
   50% - will touch base with IP. Cont to wean vent as tolerated to
   maintain O2sat >90 and PaO2 >60. Check ABG on current vent settings
   (55% fio2)
   - Wean sedation (Propofol and fentanyl gtt) as tolerated.
   - Continue meropenem for pseudomas VAP X 15 days.
   - F/u ID recs and pending cx.
   - Cont prednisone taper: D [**1-17**] of 15mg po
   - Cont low dose diuresis gtt today as long as no increased need for
   pressors or rise in BUN/Cr on pm lytes
   - Goal is run net negative hourly with minimal pressor requirement
   (neo<1)
   # Shock: BPs improved with change from zosyn to meropenem suggesting
   had resistant pseudomonas. Likely also component from conversion back
   to sinus rhythm.
   - Wean neosynephrine as tolerated
   - Cont amiodarone po
   - Continue sedation at current doses for trach today.
   # Fevers/leukocytosis: Pseudomonas VAP now on meropenem with bump in
   WBC yesterday. 1 of 2 sets ?peripheral bcx from [**6-20**] growing GPC in
   clusters while pt on linezolid but had been switched back to vanc on
   [**6-22**] due to concern for lactic acidosis; possible this may have been
   contaminant. C. diff neg x 2. CXR without change. WBC improved today
   with no change in antibiotic coverage.
   - Lines changed [**2111-6-20**]
   - Send surveillance cx
   - Continue vanc for now pending speciation of bcx
   - Continue meropenem D [**4-29**] (last dose 6/22) due to pseudomonas in
   sputum
   - Oseltamivir discontinued [**6-25**]
   # Afib: [**Month (only) 11**] be [**2-16**] overdiuresis. No e/o PE. TSH WNL. In sinus now s/p
   pharm conversion.
   - Cont amoi po (currently 200mg po BID x 7 days) for at least a few
   months
   - Cte hep gtt after trach placement given hct drop today and potential
   for trach placement.
   - hold on coumadin (CHADS2 score = 2) given need for trach/peg in next
   few days
   # Metabolic Alkalosis: Unclear etiology but did improve with
   acetazolamide earlier. Bicarb slightly higher today, may be in setting
   of diuresis although no bump in BUN/Cr
   - Recheck PM lytes; d/c lasix gtt as indicated
   # Anemia:  Had downtrended since admit w/ question of phlebotomy v.
   vaginal bleed. No active bleed visualized on exam by OB/GYN. Stools
   guaiac negative. Fe studies unrevealing. Now trending down again.
   - Repeat PM Hct
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfuse if <21 or hemodynamically unstable
   - Send T+C
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   TFs held for trach today; will need PEG in next few days
   Glycemic Control:  ISS
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2111-6-19**] 06:08 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2111-6-20**] 04:00 PM

   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:  Mouth care

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. She presented with acute-on-chronic dyspnea and was treated for H1N1 with MRSA superinfection, pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and ARDS physiology. 

The patient has several medical complications that can arise, including hypoxic respiratory failure, fluid overload, shock, fevers/leukocytosis, atrial fibrillation, metabolic alkalosis, and anemia. 

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient initially presented with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, leading to ARDS physiology. Now, she also has pseudomonas VAP. The plan is to continue weaning off the ventilator while maintaining oxygen saturation above 90% and PaO2 above 60.

2. Fluid Overload: The patient has a mild component of fluid overload with a net positive fluid balance of 15 liters over the length of stay (not accounting for insensible losses).

3. Shock: The patient's blood pressures improved with the change from zosyn to meropenem, suggesting resistant pseudomonas infection. This may also be related to the conversion back to sinus rhythm.

4. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis and fevers, likely due to pseudomonas V

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a medical history of asthma, COPD, DM, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted for acute on chronic dyspnea and treated with antibiotics for pneumonia. She is currently intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia, H1N1 influenza, and now pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). 

The patient's current vital signs include a heart rate of 55 bpm, blood pressure of 100/44 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 96%, and temperature of 37.1°C. Her ABG results show a pH of 7.49, PaCO2 of 44 mmHg, PaO2 of 117 mmHg, HCO3- of 31 mEq/L, and BE of -10 mEq/L. Her blood glucose level is 112 mg/dL, white blood cell count is 16.2 K/uL, hemoglobin is 7.4 g/dL, and platelet count is 304 K/uL.

The patient's current medications include fentanyl patch, propofol, lasix gtt, meropenem, amiodarone, and prednisone. She also has ongoing orders for lab draws, cultures, CXR, and surveillance cultures.

The patient's assessment and plan include ongoing management of hypoxic respiratory

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with acute on chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia. She developed hypoxic respiratory failure and was intubated. The patient subsequently developed MRSA and pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). She has mild fluid overload and is planned for tracheostomy placement. The patient's sedation and ventilator support are being weaned as tolerated. Antibiotic coverage has been adjusted for pseudomonas VAP. The patient also has shock, fevers, leukocytosis, atrial fibrillation, and metabolic alkalosis.

Potential Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient initially presented with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, and now has pseudomonas VAP as well. The ongoing challenge is maintaining adequate oxygenation and ventilation while weaning off sedation and ventilator support.
2. Fluid overload: The patient has a mild component of fluid overload, with 15 liters of net positive fluid balance over the length of stay (not accounting for insensible losses). Close monitoring and diuresis management are necessary to prevent further fluid accumulation.
3. Pseudomonas VAP: The patient has developed pseudomonas VAP, which is a serious complication. Appropriate antibiotic coverage with meropenem is being continued for 15 days.
4. Shock: The patient's

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted due to acute on chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia.
- The patient developed hypoxic respiratory failure and was intubated. She had an initial infection with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, followed by pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
- The patient's blood pressure improved with the change from zosyn to meropenem, suggesting resistant pseudomonas infection.
- The patient converted back to sinus rhythm, and her shock state improved.
- The patient has been weaned off neosynephrine and continues to be on meropenem for pseudomonas VAP.
- She is planned for tracheostomy placement tomorrow with goals of PEEP 10 and FiO2 50%.
- The patient's leukocytosis is likely due to pseudomonas VAP, and cultures have been ordered.
- Her fevers and leukocytosis should be monitored, and she will be followed up pending sputum culture results.
- The patient's ID recommended an 8-day course of meropenem and discontinuation of vancomycin.
- She has a history of atrial fibrillation but is currently in sinus rhythm after pharmacologic conversion.
- The patient's metabolic alkalosis is improving, and her anemia is trending down

   66 year-old female with PMH significant for asthma, COPD, DM,
   hypothyroidism with acute on chronic dyspnea, treated with antibiotics
   for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially presented with H1N1 with MRSA
   superinfection and ARDS physiology; Now with pseudomonas VAP as well.
   [**Month (only) 11**] have mild component of fluid overload as 15L net positive over LOS
   (not accounting for insensible losses).
   - Plan for trach placement on Monday as at PEEP goal of 10 and FiO2
   goal of 50% - will touch base with IP then. Cont to wean vent as
   tolerated to maintain O2sat >90 and PaO2 >60.
   - Wean sedation (Propofol and fentanyl gtt) as tolerated.
   - Continue meropenem for pseudomas VAP X 15 days to end on [**2111-7-6**].
   - F/u ID recs and pending cx.
   - Cont prednisone taper: D [**2-17**] of 15mg po
   - Cont low dose diuresis gtt today as long as no increased need for
   pressors or rise in BUN/Cr on pm lytes
   - Goal is run net negative hourly with minimal pressor requirement
   (neo<1)
   # Shock: BPs improved with change from zosyn to meropenem suggesting
   had resistant pseudomonas. Likely also component from conversion back
   to sinus rhythm.
   - Wean neosynephrine as tolerated
   - Cont amiodarone po
   - Continue sedation at current doses.
   # Fevers/leukocytosis: Pseudomonas VAP now on meropenem. 1 of 2 sets
   ?peripheral bcx from [**6-20**] growing GPC in clusters while pt on linezolid
   but had been switched back to vanc on [**6-22**] due to concern for lactic
   acidosis; possible this may have been contaminant. C. diff neg x 2. CXR
   without change.
   - Lines changed [**2111-6-20**]
   - Send surveillance cx
   - Continue meropenem x15 days (last dose 6/22) due to pseudomonas in
   sputum
   - Oseltamivir discontinued [**6-25**]; Vanc discontinued [**6-26**]
   # Afib: [**Month (only) 11**] be [**2-16**] overdiuresis. No e/o PE. TSH WNL. In sinus now s/p
   pharm conversion.
   - Cont amoi po (currently 200mg po BID x 7 days to end [**6-30**]) for at
   least a few months
   - Cte hep gtt until trach placement.
   - hold on coumadin (CHADS2 score = 2) given need for trach/peg in next
   few days
   # Metabolic Alkalosis: Unclear etiology but did improve with
   acetazolamide earlier. Bicarb slightly higher today, may be in setting
   of diuresis although no bump in BUN/Cr
   - Recheck PM lytes; d/c lasix gtt if indicated
   # Anemia:  Had downtrended since admit w/ question of phlebotomy v.
   vaginal bleed. No active bleed visualized on exam by OB/GYN. Stools
   guaiac negative. Fe studies unrevealing. Stable now
   - daily Hct
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfuse if <21 or hemodynamically unstable

She presented with acute on chronic dyspnea and was treated for pneumonia with antibiotics before being intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient has been diagnosed with impaired skin integrity, atrial fibrillation (AFIB), cough, altered mental status, anemia secondary to blood loss, fever of unknown origin, and respiratory failure. She has also been diagnosed with H1N1 infection with MRSA superinfection, ARDS physiology, and pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Impaired skin integrity: The patient may be at risk for pressure ulcers or bedsores due to prolonged immobility and increased pressure on certain areas of the body.
2. Atrial fibrillation (AFIB): The patient may be at risk for complications associated with AFIB such as stroke, heart failure, or embolic events if not properly managed.
3. Cough: The patient may develop respiratory complications such as aspiration pneumonia or further respiratory failure if the underlying cause of the cough is not addressed.
4. Altered mental status: The patient may be at risk for delirium or worsening cognitive function if not closely monitored and managed.
5. Anemia: The patient may require further evaluation and management to address the underlying cause of anemia and prevent further blood loss.

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She was initially admitted with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, and subsequently developed pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a goal PEEP of 10 and FiO2 of 50%. She has been treated with antibiotics for pneumonia and is also being treated for type I diabetes mellitus.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's skin integrity may be compromised due to prolonged immobility, pressure from the endotracheal tube, and potential infection.
2. Atrial fibrillation (AFIB): The patient has a history of AFIB, which can lead to irregular heart rhythm and potential complications such as stroke.
3. Cough: The patient may experience coughing due to irritation in the airways caused by the endotracheal tube or respiratory secretions.
4. Altered mental status (not delirium): The patient may have altered mental status due to sedation from medications or underlying medical conditions.
5. Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss (hemorrhage, bleeding): The patient may develop anemia due to blood loss during procedures or bleeding episodes.
6. Fever, unknown origin (FUO, hypertension, pyrexia): The patient may develop fever due to infection or other underlying causes

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old male admitted to the ICU with multiple comorbidities, including impaired skin integrity, atrial fibrillation, cough, altered mental status, anemia secondary to blood loss, fever of unknown origin, and type I diabetes mellitus. The patient also has acute respiratory failure not associated with ARDS. 

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.3°C, blood pressure ranging from 112/49 to 126/95 mmHg, heart rate between 61 and 79 bpm, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 168 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) set at 8 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 50%. 

The patient's laboratory results indicate an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 15.2 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) level of 8.9 g/dL, blood glucose level of 141 mg/dL, and elevated lactate level of 1.7 mmol/L. Other lab values are within normal range. 

The patient has received several medications, including fentanyl, phenylephrine, heparin, propofol, and lansoprazole. The patient's arterial and multi-lumen lines were inserted on [**2111-6-19**] and [**2111-6-20**], respectively. The patient's PICC line was placed on [**2111-6-25**]. The patient is being provided with systemic anticoagulation, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and elevation of head of bed (HOB) for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) prevention. 

The patient's current disposition is in the ICU with a code status of full code.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a [age]-year-old male with a chief complaint of altered mental status. The patient has been intubated and sedated, with an endotracheal tube in place. Vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 61 bpm, blood pressure of 112/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission.

The patient has been diagnosed with impaired skin integrity, atrial fibrillation, cough, altered mental status (not delirium), anemia secondary to blood loss, fever of unknown origin, diabetes mellitus type I, and acute respiratory failure. The patient is receiving nutrition through a feeding tube and has arterial, multi-lumen, and PICC lines in place for monitoring and medication administration. Prophylactic measures include systemic anticoagulation for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer prophylaxis with a proton pump inhibitor, and elevation of the head of bed to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: Given the patient's intubation and prolonged immobility, there is a risk of developing pneumonia due to aspiration or ventilator-associated pneumonia.

2. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for developing DVT due to immobility and the presence of central lines.

   66 year-old female with PMH significant for asthma, COPD, DM,
   hypothyroidism with acute on chronic dyspnea, treated with antibiotics
   for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially presented with H1N1 with MRSA
   superinfection and ARDS physiology; Now with pseudomonas VAP as well.
   [**Month (only) 11**] have mild component of fluid overload as 15L net positive over LOS
   (not accounting for insensible losses).
   - Plan for trach placement on Monday as at PEEP goal of 8 and FiO2 goal
   of 50% - will touch base with IP then. Cont to wean vent as tolerated
   to maintain O2sat >90 and PaO2 >60.
   - Wean sedation (Propofol and fentanyl gtt) as tolerated.
   - Continue meropenem for pseudomas VAP X 15 days to end on [**2111-7-6**].
   - F/u ID recs and pending cx.
   - Cont prednisone taper: D [**3-17**] of 15mg po. Tomorrow will have 10mg PO
   daily.
   - Cont low dose diuresis gtt today as long as no increased need for
   pressors or rise in BUN/Cr on pm lytes
   - Goal is run net negative hourly with minimal pressor requirement
   (neo<1) with 24h goal net neg 1L
   # Shock: BPs improved with change from zosyn to meropenem suggesting
   had resistant pseudomonas. Likely also component from conversion back
   to sinus rhythm.
   - Wean neosynephrine as tolerated
   - Cont amiodarone po
   - Continue sedation at current doses. Check triglycerides as has been
   on propofol several days.
   # Fevers/leukocytosis: Pseudomonas VAP now on meropenem. 1 of 2 sets
   ?peripheral bcx from [**6-20**] growing coag neg staph while pt on linezolid
   but had been switched back to vanc on [**6-22**] due to concern for lactic
   acidosis; possible this may have been contaminant. C. diff neg x 2. CXR
   without change.
   - Lines changed [**2111-6-20**]
   - Surveillance cx NGTD
   - Continue meropenem x15 days (last dose 6/22) due to pseudomonas in
   sputum
   - Oseltamivir discontinued [**6-25**]; Vanc discontinued [**6-26**]
   # Afib: [**Month (only) 11**] be [**2-16**] overdiuresis. No e/o PE. TSH WNL. In sinus now s/p
   pharm conversion.
   - Cont amiodarone po (currently 200mg po BID x 7 days to end [**6-30**]) then
   200mg PO daily
   - Cte hep gtt until trach placement.
   - hold on coumadin (CHADS2 score = 2) given need for trach/peg in next
   few days

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with acute on chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia. The patient is currently intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure. She has developed several complications including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), septic shock, atrial fibrillation, and possible central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has already developed VAP due to Pseudomonas infection. Continued ventilation and inadequate lung clearance can increase the risk of further infections or worsening of the existing VAP.
2. Septic shock: The patient's blood pressure improved with the change in antibiotic therapy, suggesting a possible resistant Pseudomonas infection causing septic shock. If not adequately managed, septic shock can lead to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome and mortality.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and it has recurred during her ICU stay. If not properly managed, atrial fibrillation can lead to embolic events such as stroke or worsen heart failure.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a medical history of asthma, COPD, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted for acute on chronic dyspnea and treated with antibiotics for pneumonia. She was intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure due to H1N1 with MRSA superinfection and ARDS physiology. The patient now has pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) as well.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient continues to have hypoxic respiratory failure initially presenting with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, now with pseudomonas VAP.
   - Plan for tracheostomy placement on Monday with a goal of PEEP of 8 and FiO2 of 50%.
   - Continue weaning off the ventilator while maintaining O2 saturation above 90% and PaO2 above 60.
   - Wean sedation (Propofol and fentanyl gtt) as tolerated.
   - Continue meropenem for pseudomonas VAP for 15 days to end on [**2111-7-6**].

2. Shock: The patient's BPs improved with the change from zosyn to meropenem, suggesting resistant pseudomonas. It is likely also related to the conversion back to sinus rhythm.
   - Wean neosynephrine as tolerated.
   - Cont amiodarone po.
   - Continue sedation at current doses. Check triglycerides as has been on propofol several days.

3. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient has pseudomonas VAP and is now on meropenem. One of the two peripheral blood cultures from [**6-20**] grew coag-negative Staph while the patient was on linezolid, but had been switched back to vancomycin on [**6-22**] due to concern for lactic acidosis; possible contaminant. C. diff negative x 2. CXR without change.
   - Lines changed [**2111-6-20**].
   - Surveillance cx NGTD.
   - Continue meropenem x15 days (last dose 6/22) due to pseudomonas in sputum.
   - Oseltamivir discontinued [**6-25**]; Vanc discontinued [**6-26**].

4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has been in atrial fibrillation since [**Month (only) 11**] and overdiuresis. No evidence of pulmonary edema. TSH within normal limits. In sinus rhythm now after pharmacological conversion.
   - Cont amiodarone po (currently 200mg po BID x 7 days to end [**6-30**]) then 200mg PO daily.
   - Continue hepatic gtt until tracheostomy placement.

Summary of the Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a medical history of asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with acute on chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia. She was intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure and diagnosed with H1N1, MRSA superinfection, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Currently, she has developed pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient also has mild fluid overload, shock, fevers, leukocytosis, atrial fibrillation (afib), metabolic alkalosis, and anemia.

She also has mild fluid overload, as indicated by a net positive fluid balance of 15 liters during her hospital stay. Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with acute on chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia. The patient developed hypoxic respiratory failure and was intubated. She has since been diagnosed with MRSA superinfection, H1N1 infection, ARDS physiology, and pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient also has mild fluid overload and is planned for tracheostomy placement. She is being weaned off the ventilator, sedation, and pressors as tolerated. Antibiotic therapy includes meropenem for pseudomonas VAP and previous treatment with oseltamivir and vancomycin. The patient is also being managed for diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and congestive heart failure. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been diagnosed with pseudomonas VAP and is currently receiving treatment with meropenem. This condition requires ongoing monitoring and appropriate antibiotic therapy.
2. Fluid overload: The patient has a mild component of fluid overload, with a net positive fluid balance of 15L over the length of stay (not accounting for insensible losses). This needs to be managed carefully to prevent complications such as pulmonary edema or worsening heart failure.
3. Shock: The patient's blood pressure improved with the change from zosyn to mer

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, DM, and hypothyroidism who presented with acute on chronic dyspnea. She was treated for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient now has pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and is on meropenem. She also has septic shock and cardiogenic shock from atrial fibrillation. The patient has been weaned off sedation and ventilation, but still requires pressors. She has been on amiodarone for atrial fibrillation. She has low-grade fevers and leukocytosis. The patient's metabolic alkalosis has been managed with acetazolamide. EKG changes suggest strain, but cardiac enzymes are negative. The patient is expected to have an outpatient workup for CAD when more stable. She is currently receiving nutritional support through enteral feeding and is being monitored closely for ICU care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has already been diagnosed with pseudomonas VAP and is being treated with meropenem. This condition requires continued aggressive treatment to prevent further deterioration.
2. Septic shock: The patient is likely experiencing septic shock due to the presence of multiple infections. Prompt and effective management of sepsis is crucial to prevent organ dysfunction and mortality.
3. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, and normal platelet count. Other lab values are within normal range.

3. Pseudomonas Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient has developed VAP, which increases the risk of morbidity and mortality if not appropriately treated.
4. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient's low-grade fever and leukocytosis

5. Delirium: The patient exhibits altered mental status, which may be due to various factors including the underlying medical conditions, medications, or sepsis. Close monitoring for signs

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year-old female with PMH significant for asthma, COPD, DM,
   hypothyroidism with acute on chronic dyspnea, treated with antibiotics
   for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
    # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially presented with H1N1 with MRSA
   superinfection and ARDS physiology; Now with pseudomonas VAP as well.
   Trach placed [**6-30**].
   - Cont to wean vent and sedation (d/c fentanyl as on patch, start
   valium po, wean down propofol) as tolerated to maintain O2sat >90 and
   PaO2 >60.
   - Lidocaine to calm bronchospasms
   - Continue meropenem for pseudomas VAP X 15 days to end on [**2111-7-6**].
   - Cont prednisone taper: D2/3 of 10mg po today.
   - Transition lasix gtt to bolus doses if maintains U/O; also resume
   acetazolamide. Goal is run net negative hourly with minimal pressor
   requirement (neo<1) with 24h goal net neg
   # Shock: Likely septic as well as cardiogenic from AF now continued
   need for pressors in setting of sedation
   - Wean sedation as tolerated as above
   - Wean neosynephrine as tolerated
   -  Cont amiodarone po
    # Fevers/leukocytosis: Pt with low grade fever last pm, leukocytosis
   stable for last week at around 14-15. On meropenem for pseudomonal VAP.
   - Lactate negative
   - UA with sm leukesterase. Would change foley, start fluconazole today
   given multiple positive ucx with yeast.
   - Continue meropenem x 15 days (last dose 6/22) due to pseudomonas in
   sputum
   - F/u cultures and send C-diff
   - Attempt peripheral IVs and pull CVL today if no longer need as many
   ports
   # Metabolic alkalosis
   - Resume acetazolamide
   # EKG changes c/w strain: Cardiac enzymes flat. If she had an event it
   was many days ago as trops neg now.
   - Cte ASA (change to NG)
   - Unable to tolerate beta blocker or ACE given borderline BPs
   - [**Month (only) 11**] need o/p workup for CAD when more stable

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, DM, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with acute on chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia. The patient developed hypoxic respiratory failure and was intubated. She also has pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been weaned off fentanyl and propofol, but still requires pressors for blood pressure support. She has been started on fluconazole for urine yeast and valium for sedation. The patient's current medications include lansoprazole, heparin sodium, and furosemide.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient initially presented with H1N1 with MRSA superinfection and ARDS physiology. Now, she has pseudomonas VAP as well. There is a continued need for ventilatory support and weaning off sedation while maintaining oxygen saturation above 90% and PaO2 above 60.

2. Shock: The patient is likely experiencing septic shock due to suspected pseudomonas VAP and cardiogenic shock from atrial fibrillation. There is a continued need for pressor support, weaning sedation, and monitoring for hemodynamic stability.

3. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient has a low-grade fever and stable leukocytosis around 14-15. This could be related to the ongoing infection and should be monitored with frequent cultures and appropriate antibiotic coverage.

4. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has metabolic alkalosis, which may be related to diuretic use (furosemide) and respiratory alkalosis due to mechanical ventilation. Acetazolamide can be resumed to help correct the metabolic alkalosis.

5. EKG Changes: The patient has EKG changes suggestive of strain, but cardiac enzymes are flat, indicating no recent myocardial infarction.

Potential Medical Complications in ICU Care:
1. Nutritional Support: The patient is receiving Nutren Pulmonary (Full) at 30 mL/hour.

2. Glycemic Control: The patient's glycemic control should be monitored and managed as per ICU protocol.

3. Lines: The patient has multiple lines including an arterial line, multi-lumen central line, and a PICC line.

4. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Overall, the patient's condition remains critical, and close monitoring and management of her respiratory status, hemodynamics, infection, and other medical complications are essential in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a significant medical history of asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia. The patient developed hypoxic respiratory failure and was intubated.

The patient initially presented with H1N1 infection and MRSA superinfection, but now she is being treated for Pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) as well. There is persistence of Gram-negative bacilli on the sputum gram stain sent yesterday.

The patient's tracheostomy placement on June 30th was successful, and she tolerated a tracheostomy mask trial yesterday, which is encouraging. The plan is to continue weaning off the ventilator and sedation while maintaining oxygen saturation above 90% and PaO2 above 60.

The patient is on meropenem for Pseudomonas VAP for an additional 15 days until July 6th. There is consideration to add gentamicin or tobramycin for double coverage. The prednisone taper will be continued, and the patient will be weaned off propofol as tolerated.

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, DM, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted with acute on chronic dyspnea and treated for pneumonia. She developed hypoxic respiratory failure and required intubation. She was diagnosed with MRSA superinfection and ARDS physiology. She is currently being treated for pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and has persistent gram-negative bacilli on sputum gram stain. The patient has shown improvement in tolerating tracheostomy mask trials. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient initially presented with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, leading to ARDS physiology. She is now on treatment for pseudomonas VAP. The persistence of GNB on sputum gram stain suggests ongoing infection, which could lead to worsening respiratory failure if not effectively managed.
2. Septic Shock: The patient is likely septic, as indicated by low-grade fever and leukocytosis. This could progress to septic shock, especially if the source of infection is not controlled.
3. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiac enzymes are flat, suggesting no recent cardiac event. However, her history of AFib increases the risk of cardiogenic shock due to arrhythmias.
4. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has metabolic alkalosis, which is improving with acetazolamide. Discontin

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a medical history significant for asthma, COPD, DM, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted for acute on chronic dyspnea and treated with antibiotics for pneumonia. The patient required intubation for hypoxic respiratory failure initially presenting with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, as well as ARDS physiology. She is now being treated for pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and has persistence of gram-negative bacilli (GNB) on sputum gram stain sent yesterday.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient is on treatment for pseudomonas VAP, along with continuing efforts to wean off sedation and ventilation. Daily trach trials are encouraged.
2. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient has low-grade fever and leukocytosis, which is stable at around 13-15. She is on meropenem for pseudomonal VAP, but sputum culture still shows GNB. Fluconazole was started for multiple UCX positive for yeast.
3. Shock: The patient likely has septic shock as well as cardiogenic shock from atrial fibrillation. MAP >60 is being maintained off pressors as sedation is being weaned off.
4. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient's metabolic alkalosis is improving on acetazolamide, which is being discontinued today.
5. EKG Changes c/w Strain: Cardiac enzymes are flat. If the patient had an event, it was many days ago, as troponin levels are negative.
6. Nutrition: The patient is receiving Nutren Pulmonary (Full) at 45 mL/hour.
7. Glycemic Control: The patient's blood glucose levels are being monitored.
8. Lines: The patient has an arterial line, PICC line, and central venous line (CVL) in place.
9. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving SQ heparin for DVT prophylaxis, lansoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis, and meropenem for pseudomonas VAP.
10. Communication: The patient's family members have been informed about her condition.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pseudomonas VAP: The patient has persistent GNB in the sputum, indicating a potential ongoing infection.
2. Yeast Infection: The patient has UCX positive for yeast, indicating a potential fungal infection.
3. Shock: The patient's low blood pressure and the need for pressors suggest ongoing shock, which could be septic or cardiogenic in nature.
4. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient's metabolic alkalosis is improving but may require further management.
5. EKG Changes: Although cardiac enzymes are flat, the EKG changes suggest strain on the heart, which may require further evaluation.
6. Hypoxia: The patient's respiratory status may continue to pose a risk for hypoxia.
7. DVT/PE: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to prolonged immobility and central venous lines.
8. Nosocomial Infections: The patient is at risk for acquiring additional nosocomial infections due to prolonged ICU stay and invasive lines.

Please note that this summary and potential medical complications are based on the provided progress note.

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. She presented with acute on chronic dyspnea and was treated for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient initially had H1N1 with MRSA superinfection and ARDS physiology. Currently, she is being treated for pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with intermediate sensitivity to meropenem. The patient's arterial line and PICC line have stopped, and blood cultures were obtained. She has a fever of 102.0°F and is experiencing tachycardia. The patient's tracheostomy trial failed due to fever and tachycardia, but she converted from atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (A-fib w/ RVR) to sinus rhythm prior to administering metoprolol. Blood cultures from July 1st showed budding yeast, and the patient was advised to discontinue fluconazole and start micafungin. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) has been ordered for possible endocarditis. Sputum cultures from July 1st revealed pseudomonas with intermediate sensitivity to meropenem, but tobramycin was not given. The patient's intravenous (IV) lines were pulled for line holiday, and two peripheral IVs (PIVs) were placed. The patient's cuff

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a medical history significant for asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypothyroidism. She presented with acute-on-chronic dyspnea and was treated for pneumonia. The patient required intubation due to hypoxic respiratory failure initially caused by H1N1 with MRSA superinfection and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) physiology. She is now being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, as well as persistent gram-negative bacilli (GNB) on sputum gram stain.

The patient has shown some improvement, including tolerating a tracheostomy mask trial yesterday and encouraging progress. The plan is to continue weaning the patient off sedation and ventilation while maintaining oxygen saturation above 90% and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) above 60. Daily tracheostomy trials will be conducted, gradually increasing the time spent off the ventilator.

The patient's fevers and leukocytosis have been stable for the past week, with a white blood cell count ranging from 13-15. Despite being on meropenem for pseudomonal VAP, the sputum culture still shows growth of GNB. Fluconazole was started yesterday for multiple urine cultures positive for yeast, and yeast was also found in the blood culture drawn from an arterial

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old female with a chief complaint of fever and tachycardia. She has a history of diabetes mellitus type I, respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, anemia secondary to blood loss, cough, and impaired skin integrity. The patient's arterial line and PICC line were stopped on 07/03/2111. Blood cultures were taken on 07/04/2111 at 04:48 AM. The patient was given metoprolol 5 mg twice due to fever and tachycardia, but converted to sinus rhythm prior to dose. Blood culture from 07/01 showed budding yeast, and the ID recommended micafungin and discontinuation of fluconazole. Sputum culture from 07/01 showed pseudomonas with intermediate sensitivity to meropenem, but tobramycin was not given. The patient has two PIVs placed and all lines pulled for line holiday. The patient's allergies include levofloxacin. The last doses of antibiotics were tobramycin on 07/03/2111 at 04:00 PM, micafungin on 07/03/2111 at 09:44 PM, and meropenem on 07/04/2111 at 04:00 AM. The patient is currently on furosemide (Lasix) at 01:52 AM on 07/04/2111. 

The patient's vital signs include a maximum temperature of 38.9 degrees Celsius (102 degrees Fahrenheit), current temperature of 37.6 degrees Celsius (99.6 degrees Fahrenheit), heart rate of 107 bpm with a range of 86-135 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 158/61 mmHg to 90/43 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute with a range of 17-33 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on SpO2. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus tachycardia. 

The patient's fluid balance shows a total intake of 1,687 mL with 559 mL given intravenously, 1,081 mL given orally, and 502 mL given intravenously with 100 mL given in the last 24 hours. The total output includes 1,480 mL of urine output, -116 mL of balance, and unknown amounts of NG, stool, and drain output. 

The patient's respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV ventilation mode with a tidal volume of 415 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O, fractional inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%, and respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 48. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows pH of 7.32, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) of 32 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) of 75 mmHg. 

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell (WBC) count of 13.0 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) level of 10.4 g/dL, platelet (Plt) count of 326 K/uL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 60 mg/dL, creatinine (Cr) level of 0.7 mg/dL, sodium (Na+) level of 140 mEq/L, potassium (K+) level of 3.6 mEq/L, chloride (Cl-) level of 98 mEq/L, glucose level of 230 mg/dL, and calcium (Ca++) level of 9.2 mg/dL. Other lab results are within normal range. 

The patient's assessment and plan include cardiac dysrhythmia, impaired skin integrity, cough, altered mental status, acute anemia secondary to blood loss, fever of unknown origin, diabetes mellitus type I, acute respiratory failure, and other conditions. The patient is receiving ICU care including nutrition, glycemic control

   - Cont lasix IV 160mg TID with 24h goal net neg U/O without restarting

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year-old female with PMH significant for asthma, COPD, DM,
   hypothyroidism with acute on chronic dyspnea, treated with antibiotics
   for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
    # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially presented with H1N1 with MRSA
   superinfection and ARDS physiology; now on tx for pseudomonas VAP as
   well with persistence of GNB on sputum gram stain sent yestserday.
   Trach placed [**6-30**] and ability to tolerate trach mask trial yesterday
   encouraging.
   - Cont to wean vent and sedation  as tolerated to maintain O2sat >90
   and PaO2 >60. Stop valium today and [**Month (only) 202**] fentanyl dose. Attempt to wean
   propofol today.
   - trach trials daily as tolerated with increased time off vent each day
   as able
   - Lidocaine to calm bronchospasms
   - Continue meropenem for pseudomonas VAP X 15 days to end on [**2111-7-6**];
   consider adding ? gent or tobra for double coverage based on
   sensitivities.
   - Cont prednisone taper: D3/3 of 10mg po today; wean to 5mg po tomorrow
   - d/c acetazolamide
   - Cont lasix IV 160mg TID with 24h goal net neg U/O without restarting
   pressors. Check PM lytes.
   # Fevers/leukocytosis: Pt with low grade fever yesterday; leukocytosis
   stable for last week at around 13-15. On meropenem for pseudomonal VAP
   but sputum cx still with GNB. Started on fluconazole yesterday for
   multiple ucx positive for yeast. Yeast growing from BCx from [**7-1**] drawn
   from a-line.
   - Continue meropenem x 15 days (last dose 6/22) due to pseudomonas in
   sputum; consider adding 2^nd [**Doctor Last Name 23**] as above
   - Change fluconazole to IV. Call micro lab to speciate whether albicans
   which is more sensitive to fluc.
   - Call ID to consider other abx instead if fluc not adequate
   - F/u cultures
   - Pull a-line, PICC, PIV and resite CVL with left subclavian
   - Consider cls ophtho and TTE in the next few days for candidemia

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. She presented with acute on chronic dyspnea and was treated for H1N1 pneumonia with MRSA superinfection. She developed ARDS physiology and required intubation. The patient has since been diagnosed with pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and has persistent gram-negative bacilli (GNB) in her sputum gram stain. She also has candidemia as indicated by positive blood cultures for budding yeast. The patient has been on multiple antibiotics, including meropenem and fluconazole, but the infection persists. She is currently on mechanical ventilation support and is being weaned off sedation as tolerated. The plan is to continue meropenem for pseudomonas VAP for another 15 days, and to consider adding gentamicin or tobramycin for double coverage based on sensitivities. She will also be started on micafungin due to the presence of candidemia. The patient's tracheostomy tube was replaced yesterday, and she tolerated it well. Her arterial line and PICC line were stopped previously due to infection. The patient's fever and leukocytosis are being monitored, and further investigations are planned to determine the cause of the persistent infection.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure, H1N1 infection, and fungemia. They have been experiencing fevers, arterial and PICC line stops, blood cultures taken, and conversion of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) after administration of a beta-blocker. The patient also has no spontaneous left arm movement. Allergies include Levofloxacin, and the last dose of antibiotics was given on 07-03. Infusions include furosemide, lansoprazole, and heparin sodium. The patient's medical history, social history, family history, and review of systems are unchanged from admission except for the noted changes above. 

Vital signs show a maximum temperature of 102.0°F, heart rate between 86-135 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 90/43 mmHg to 158/71 mmHg, respiratory rate between 17-33 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's height is 62 inches, and their weight is not specified. Fluid balance shows an intake of 1,687 mL total in, including 771 mL of PO, 502 mL of IVF, and 100 mL of TF. Output includes 1,480 mL of total out, consisting of 925 mL of urine, 207 mL of NG, and -154 mL of drain balance. Respiratory support is provided through a tracheostomy tube with CPAP/PSV mode ventilation. Oxygen delivery is set at 50%, with PS of 8 cmH2O, RR of 24 breaths per minute, PEEP of 8 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 50%. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.32, PaCO2 of 32 mmHg, PaO2 of 60 mmHg, HCO3- of 21 mEq/L, and BE of -10 mEq/L. Ve is 11.2 L/min.

Physical examination reveals a tracheostomy, lying in bed, HEENT with reactive pupils though right slower than left, CV with RR, chest with coarse bilateral breath sounds, abdomen as obese soft NT, extremities with 1+ edema, and neurologic with spontaneous movement of all extremities except for the left arm. 

Lab results show a WBC count of 13.0 K/uL, Hct of 31.1%, Plt of 457 K/uL, Cr of 0.7 mg/dL, TCO2 of 33 mmHg, glucose levels ranging from 128-230 mg/dL, and other lab values within normal limits. Urine yeast is present.

Assessment and plan:
1. Resp Failure: Continue PSV wean with daily TM trials and ongoing steroid taper.
2. New Fevers: Discontinue all

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing acute respiratory failure, which requires ongoing management and weaning off mechanical ventilation.
2. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient has had persistent fevers despite antibiotic coverage, indicating a possible infection that needs further investigation.
3. Fungemia: The patient has been diagnosed with fungemia, which is a systemic fungal infection. Appropriate antifungal therapy has been initiated, and all central lines have been removed.
4. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient has coarse bilateral crackles in the chest, suggesting potential lung damage or impaired skin integrity.
5. Cardiac Dysrhythmia: The patient was initially in atrial fibrillation (AFib) but was successfully converted to sinus rhythm. Ongoing management of the patient's heart rhythm is necessary.
6. Altered Mental Status: The patient has shown signs of altered mental status, which is being closely monitored and managed.
7. Anemia: The patient has acute anemia secondary to blood loss during their illness. Blood product transfusions have been administered as needed.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to H1N1 infection and fungemia. The patient has been experiencing fevers, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, altered mental status, anemia secondary to blood loss, and diabetes mellitus type 1. The patient requires respiratory support through a tracheostomy tube and mechanical ventilation in CPAP/PSV mode. There are concerns regarding impaired skin integrity, cough, and altered mental status. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure needs continuous monitoring and management. Weaning from mechanical ventilation should be done cautiously, considering the ongoing steroid taper.
2. Infection: The presence of yeast in urine and blood suggests a possible fungal infection. All lines need to be removed, and appropriate antifungal therapy should be initiated. Consultation with an infectious disease specialist is recommended for further coverage and management.
3. Endophthalmitis: The patient requires an ophthalmology consult for potential endophthalmitis, which is an infection of the inside of the eye.
4. Cardiac Issues: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response needs to be managed carefully. Antiarrhythmic medication should be considered, and the patient's cardiac function should be monitored closely.
5. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity should be assessed regularly to prevent or manage any potential pressure ulcers or infections.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a significant medical history of asthma, COPD, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. She presented with acute on chronic dyspnea and was treated for pneumonia with antibiotics. The patient was intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure. She has been diagnosed with candidemia, with yeast growing from blood cultures and unidentified organisms from the PICC tip culture. A suboptimal transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) showed no evidence of vegetation, but there is concern for an embolic event. The patient has been started on micafungin and continues to receive meropenem for pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). She has been weaned off the ventilator and is now on a tracheostomy mask. The patient's respiratory status is improving daily, and further diuresis has been held. She also has atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and a CHADS2 score of 1. There is concern for an embolic event, and a repeat CT head in 48 hours is being considered if there is no movement of the left arm. The patient's bowel regimen needs to be increased due to constipation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Candidemia: The patient has yeast growing from blood cultures, indicating candidemia. It is important to continue antifungal therapy and monitor for any signs of worsening infection.

There is no evidence of endophthalmitis or vegetation on the echocardiogram, which was of suboptimal quality. There is concern for an embolic event, including a possible stroke, but this has not been confirmed on imaging. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. She presented with acute on chronic dyspnea and was treated for pneumonia. The patient required intubation due to hypoxic respiratory failure. She has been diagnosed with candidemia caused by C. parapsilosis and is currently being treated with micafungin. The patient also has a persistent pseudomonas infection in her respiratory tract, which is thought to be a colonizer and not requiring a change in antibiotic therapy. There is concern for an embolic event, but no vegetations were seen on the transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). The patient is on anticoagulation therapy and is being monitored closely.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Candidemia: The patient has an active infection of C. parapsilosis, which is a type of yeast infection. This can lead to further systemic spread and potential complications if not treated effectively.

2. Pseudomonas infection: Although considered a colonizer, the persistent presence of pseudomonas in the respiratory tract may increase the risk of respiratory failure or worsening of the patient's current condition.

3. Embolic event: There have been concerns about the possibility of an embolic event, possibly related to atrial fibrillation or other cardiac issues. Monitoring and appropriate management are crucial to prevent any potential complications.

4. Thromboembolic

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a significant medical history of asthma, COPD, DM, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted for acute on chronic dyspnea and treated with antibiotics for pneumonia. The patient required intubation due to hypoxic respiratory failure. She has had various complications during her stay in the ICU, including suspected embolic events, fungemia, and persistent pseudomonas infection.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Embolic events: The patient initially had no movement in her left arm, raising concerns for an embolic event. Although a CT head was done, it did not show any acute intracranial process. However, the patient was observed to have spontaneous movement later in the day. It is important to monitor for any further signs or symptoms of embolic events.

2. Fungemia: The patient has yeast growing from blood cultures, indicating a fungal infection. Despite a change in Foley catheter, yeast is also present in the urine cultures. Additionally, there are unidentified organisms from the PICC line tip culture. The patient is currently on micafungin, and further surveillance blood and mycologic cultures are planned. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) may be considered to assess for endocarditis.

3. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient initially presented with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, leading to ARDS physiology. She is currently being treated for pseud

The patient is currently intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure. She has been diagnosed with H1N1, MRSA superinfection, ARDS physiology, and pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient also has a yeast infection, likely candidemia, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pseudomonas VAP: The patient's current infection with pseudomonas VAP poses a risk for worsening respiratory failure and possible sepsis.
2. Candidemia: The presence of yeast growth from blood cultures indicates a systemic fungal infection, which can lead to disseminated candidiasis if not treated promptly.
3. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (AFib with RVR): The patient's history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response increases the risk of thromboembolic events, such as stroke.
4. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's initial presentation with hypoxic respiratory failure indicates severe lung compromise, which can progress to further respiratory deterioration.
5. Tracheostomy Cuff Leak: The concern for a tracheostomy cuff leak may result in aspiration pneumonia and worsening respiratory status.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She was admitted for acute on chronic dyspnea and treated with antibiotics for pneumonia. She is intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient has candidemia and a line-associated bloodstream infection, both of which are being treated with micafungin. She also has pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is being treated with meropenem. The patient's respiratory status is improving daily, but there is persistent pseudomonas in the sputum cultures. She has been weaned off the ventilator and is now on a tracheostomy mask. The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and a CHADS2 score of 1. She is currently in sinus rhythm and will continue to be monitored on tele. The patient is also being considered for anticoagulation therapy. There is a concern for an embolic event, but no vegetations were seen on the transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). The patient's left arm was initially thought to be without movement, but she is now moving all extremities. The patient also has constipation and will have her bowel regimen increased. The patient's vital signs are stable, and she is receiving appropriate ICU care including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer,

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of asthma, COPD, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She presented with acute on chronic dyspnea and was treated for pneumonia. She required intubation due to hypoxic respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Embolic event: The patient's left arm was initially observed to be without movement, but later it was noted to have spontaneous movement. This raises concern for a possible embolic event, especially considering the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and recent use of heparin. A repeat CT head in 48 hours is planned if concern remains.
2. Fungemia: Yeast is growing from blood cultures, indicating a possible fungal infection. The source of infection may be the urinary catheter or the intravenous line. The patient has already started on micafungin and will continue surveillance blood and mycologic cultures. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) may be considered to assess for endocarditis.
3. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient initially presented with H1N1 and MRSA superinfection, leading to ARDS physiology. She is currently being treated for pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Despite antibiotic therapy, pseudomonas continues to be present in sputum cultures, but these organisms are thought to be respiratory colonizers. Fever attributed to fungemia is expected to improve with micaf

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is critically ill and has several medical complications. These include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on a ventilator (TM) for 24 hours and is experiencing ongoing steroid taper.
2. New fevers: The patient has low-grade fevers, and the source is unknown. The patient is being monitored for sepsis, and daily blood cultures are being taken. The patient is also on micafungin for a positive fungal blood culture.
3. Total body volume overload: The patient has been diuresed with lasix, but the BUN levels are increasing. The diuretic dose needs to be decreased by half, aiming for a negative fluid balance of 1-2 liters per day.
4. Pneumonia (PNA): The patient will continue receiving vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and azithromycin for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) for another 15 days (ending on [**7-6**]). The patient has worsening secretions, and a chest CT scan is stable to slightly improved. The patient's cough is ongoing, and they may benefit from nebulized lidocaine for comfort.
5. Rapid ventricular response (RVR): The patient will be managed with amiodarone for atrial fibrillation with RVR. The patient will continue aspirin but hold off on coumadin.
6. Mental status: The

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is critically ill and currently admitted to the ICU. They have a history of cardiac dysrhythmia, impaired skin integrity, cough, altered mental status, anemia secondary to blood loss, fever of unknown origin, and diabetes mellitus type I. The patient also has acute respiratory failure and requires mechanical ventilation. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 77 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 123/68 to 137/85 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on T-piece with SpO2.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiac Dysrhythmia: The patient has a history of cardiac dysrhythmia, specifically atrial fibrillation (AFIB). This condition can lead to irregular heart rhythms and potentially compromise cardiac output, causing symptoms such as dizziness, fainting, or even cardiac arrest if left unmanaged.
2. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient has impaired skin integrity, which increases the risk of pressure ulcers or bedsores. These ulcers can be painful, difficult to heal, and may lead to infection if not properly managed.
3. Cough: The patient presents with a cough. If persistent or severe, this can indicate underlying respiratory issues, such as pneumonia or bronchitis. In a critically ill patient, it may suggest the need for further evaluation and treatment to prevent complications like

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 62-inch, 83 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of fever and altered mental status. They have a history of diabetes mellitus type I and respiratory failure. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for cough. On examination, the patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure of 130/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on T-piece. The patient is now out of bed and sitting in a chair. They have a tracheostomy in place and are on mechanical ventilation. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count and creatinine levels, but overall stable parameters. The patient's blood cultures grew C. parapsilosis and coag-negative staphylococcus from the PICC catheter tip. The patient was started on a 14-day course of antifungal treatment and a 15-day course of meropenem for pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Prednisone was discontinued as the taper was completed. The patient's mental status is improving, and they are expected to continue weaning from the ventilator.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year-old female with PMH significant for asthma, COPD, DM,
   hypothyroidism with acute on chronic dyspnea, treated with antibiotics
   for pneumonia and intubated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
   # Candidemia: C. PARAPSILOSIS growing from BCx from [**7-1**] drawn from
   a-line as well. Ucx also persistently growing yeast. PICC tip cx with
   Coag neg Staph, presumed contaminant given no growth on other bcx to
   date. Suboptimal TTE without evidence of vegetation. No endophtalmitis
   on exam.
   - On micafungin (D1 [**2111-7-3**])
   - Cont line holiday as long as possible
   - Cont daily surveillance mycolytic and routine blood cx tmrw
   - Appreciate ID input; f/u recs
   - Appreciate Ophtho eval
    # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially presented with H1N1 with MRSA
   superinfection and ARDS physiology. Trach and PEG on [**2111-6-29**]; now on tx
   for pseudomonas VAP with persistence of pseudomonas+ sputum cultures,
   thought to be respiratory colonizers with fevers attributed to
   fungemia.
   - Complete meropenem course today for pseudomonas VAP X 15 days.
   Consider BAL per ID recs if respiratory status worsens but currently
   improving daily.
   - Weaned off vent to trach mask. Now off propofol and valium - cont to
   decrease dose of fentanyl patch q3d.
   - Completed prednisone taper (last dose [**2111-7-4**])
   - F/u CT chest final read
   - D/c
ed lasix as BUN bumping; will reassess after I/O check in PM with
   goal net even
   # AFib with RVR: CHADS2 score 1. Had been on heparin but was stopped
   about 1 week ago as was felt to be just lone Afib but has had several
   self-limited episodes of recurrence; currently in sinus.
   - Continue to monitor on tele
   - Increase ASA to full dose; could consider starting coumadin
   - Cont amiodarone low dose beta blocker for long term rate control as
   pressures allow with prn beta blocker doses for rate control
   # Concern for embolic event: L arm thought to be without movement and R
   pupil sluggish but CT head without acute intracranial process and now
   moving all extremities although LUE somewhat less than RUE. Of note,
   recent afib with CHADS 2 on heparin gtt until switched to ASA and hep
   SQ several days ago. No vegetations seen on TTE.
   - Hold further imaging for now; consider repeat CT head in 48 hours
   ([**7-6**]) if concern remains
   # Constipation: Increase bowel regimen
   ICU Care
